ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about computer architecture and how computers work at a low level.

This class is hard. It starts off easy enough but quickly turns very difficult if you don't keep up with all the material presented in every lecture. Also, there's going to be a lot of material that you have to self-study.

I gained knowledge on how to develop truth tables, construct simple circuits with logic gates, construct and analyze the timing of sequential circuits, build more complex systems with circuit modules, and how to analyze control and datapaths of more complicated processors.
I learned the foundations of how computers work from the ground up.
Learned Boolean algebra, designing circuit logic, finite statement machines, memory and cpu architecture
You learn a sh*t ton from this class from basic logic gates to computer implementations.

The course is a nice opportunity to learn some basic verilog programming and concepts of the underlying hardware for a basic processor. One of the more enjoyable ee required classes. As a cs major, it's a nice complement to Cs323. Learning the hardware half of the software/hardware interface of computers.

Read the textbook and you'll do well. Or just pay attention to lecture.

I learned the basics of computer engineering. In particular, we covered transistors, Boolean algebra, logic gates, combinational logic, sequential logic (flip-flops and finite state machines), the arithmetic logic unit, and von Neumann architecture of computer (MIPS and LC-3).

I got a great introduction to the field of computer engineering, from the low-level aspects (transistors, gates) to higher-level aspects (ISA, microarchitecture). I learned how to solve boolean minimization problems, design Moore/Mealy FSMs and implement them using gates/wires, perform timing analyses, use Verilog for electronics problems, and apply MIPS and LC-3 assembly. In terms of insights, I was exposed to the field of computer engineering and the interface between computer science and electrical engineering.
Computer architecture fundamentals
I now understand how computers work at a very fundamental level. I also know programming in Verilog.
The basic computer design and architecture principles.
Basic understanding computer architecture and
I learned about computer engineering all the way from boolean algebra and logic gates to ISAs and microarchitecture.
A pretty in-depth and applicable survey of computer logic and architecture.

Digital logic, from Boolean algebra, through basic combinational logic gates, to larger logic blocks, sequential logic design, and eventually the design of a basic von Neumann microprocessor (LC3, mips). Lab sections follow along with exercises in Verilog.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I enjoyed the labs! They were challenging but fun.
I think that the course was well taught but sometimes the information was presented in a confusing way.
If more context can be given to the material then a lot more students would understand what's going on.

Most of the beginning half of this course was well taught and relatively interesting. That being said, the pacing of the course was insane. I do not think I have been in a course before where so much information had to be processed so fast to keep up. Part of the problem was that Professor Panda wrote all of the annotations on the slides instead of writing them during class, this turned times that she should have been writing on the board for us to follow along and process information into tests of how fast one could physically copy down notes. There were also many parts of the course where the topics covered were too complicated to put on the exams (such as going over a 4/4 divider circuit). If these parts were cut out and the time gained from them was used to spend more time on the material that was covered too fast I think the course would greatly improve. Additionally, the last 4-5 weeks of class consisted mostly of staring at the diagrams of LC-3 and MIPS processors and talking about them until they made sense. There is no way that this is the most effective way to teach this topic. I am not sure specifically how one could teach about these processors in a better way but I am confident there is one.

At times the information was really interesting, but some lectures were extremely boring. We spent way too much time on adders, and I would have liked to do more examples in class. Labs were hard and exhuasting.

Course covers a lot of content. The lectures were sometimes hard to follow, but more of the shear volume of content we learned. On the other hand, you really get some scope on how cpus work and its cool to see how far youve come at the end.

Strength: labs are fun and you learn A LOT.
Weakness: Too much content crammed into one class.  Not a lot of practice material outside of coursework for us to master the content, so I would say it focused more on breadth rather than depth. The midterm practical was not a great experience - we had maybe two lectures on Verilog code, definitely not experts. There is a lot of workload for this class, be prepared to spend over 15 hours on labs and assignments combined in some weeks.

Strengths: the course is really interesting and the problem sets are quite extensive. The labs are also very useful.

Weaknesses: the pace of the course (especially in the second half) was really fast, and we did have to refer other sources than the main textbook. Also, the final included material covered in class but not on the problem sets.

Strengths: Professor Panda, posted lecture slides are complete and have lots of examples, exams are fair and based on the content learned in lecture, flow of class from low-level to high-level concepts is very natural

Suggestions for improvement: Would be helpful to have more ULA availability
Lectures were unclear. It would be better to have more slightly smaller problem sets to practice the concepts

The labs were great! Using a FPGA board we got to program into existence different parts of a computer processor. Most importantly, I learned Verilog which is a super valuable industry skill. The lectures went too fast for me, but the textbook was good, so most of the time I didn't go to class and just read the textbook instead.
lighten content of lectures

Strengths: passionate, committed professor

Weaknesses: the labs were very difficult if you don't have prior coding experience. FPGA code is not very intuitive and very hard to debug (especially, as I said, if you are new to coding)
Lectures moved too quickly

Good content; only 1 TA with limited additional resources. The textbook is pretty good, but other than that it's difficult to get outside help. However, Panda was great about setting up meetings when I missed classes due to covid.
Great class! Well organized structure-follows great textbooks which are translated into good slides.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in learning about computer architecture and how computers work. That being said, if you don't have some experience with programming ideas you will probably find this class challenging.
If you're willing to put in the work and have an already solid understanding/love for EE.

Not particularly. I thought the labs were interesting and somewhat fun and that many of the topics covered were eye openning as an EECS major. That being said, I am not sure that it would be worth the amount of confusion and terrible pacing for the majority of people.
Yes, if you need it for your major, if you are just interested in the class take it for fun.
Its not for everyone, but the course really teaches you a lot about computer architecture and its very rewarding seeing how much knowledge is built up over the year.

This course completely changed from past years and the workload was a lot greater. There was a lot of content covered, but I wouldn't necessarily say it was a lot harder than other engineering classes. Be prepared to do a LOT for this class including labs and assignments. If you don't have a good CS background, all I can say is good luck and rip. Be prepared to learn how to code in Verilog in two lectures.
I would recommend this course because it is really interesting, but be aware that the material can be quite challenging.

YES - absolutely!! This is an amazing class if you are in EE, EECS, CS, or any engineering / physical sciences major. The principles that you will learn in this course are foundational to further study in many fields. More abstractly, the process of taking a complex problem and distilling it to the most essential parts is a really important skill that you will take away from EENG 201. You can take EENG 201 before or after EENG 200.
The material in this class is very relevant for any form of computer engineering. However, the lectures were a real mess and most of us learned all the material at the last minute.

If you want to fundamentally understand how a computer works, then yes. You build up a conceptual understanding of the CPU from the transistor level, which was so cool! The labs require a lot of programming--some of which at points can feel mundane and frustrating-- so be prepared for that (I didn't personally like programming in Verilog, but some students did). Kevin Ryan, who runs the lab space is AMAZING.
If you are interested in computer architecture, I'd definitely recommend this course. I really felt like I learned a lot.
yes, it gives valuable insight into the fundamentals of how computers function on a lower level

Recommend, potentially as a Credit/D, for those interested in how computers work at a very low level. The work and the exams are difficult but fair. Course content is interesting, although could be presented in a more interactive way.
Yes! Required for EE, but also great for anyone interested in the basics of digital logic. Also helpful to get some hands on experience with Verilog!
